title-group.article-title: Design and analysis of multifunctional structures with embedded electronics for thermomechanical loads

article-meta.aff: School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Purdue University, USA

author-notes.corresp: Rushabh Kothari, School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, USA. Email: rushabh.kothari@alumni.purdue.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Multifunctional structures, of various forms, are being used in aerospace industry and there have been increasing efforts to enhance their performance. The design and analysis of a composite sandwich beam embedded avionics and integrated cooling systems is presented in this article. The integrated electronics inside a sandwich beam reduces the overall weight of a vehicle by eliminating most of the avionics housing, cables, interconnects, etc. The foam core of a sandwich beam is modified with a cavity to embed avionics. Since the presence of a cavity degrades the strength of the structure, various methods of reinforcement have been presented. The heat dissipation system has been designed to protect the structure from excessive thermal loads. The design of heat dissipating system consists of two parts, thermal interface materials and a highly efficient heat transfer device. Design guidelines for a thermal interface material consisting of particulate composites are presented here. Among various choices, heat pipes have been chosen as the preferred heat transfer device. An example is given for an unmanned aerial vehicle skin acting as the heat sink to maintain embedded electronics within their operational limit at subsonic air speeds.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Traditional structural components are designed primarily as load-bearing structures. Transition from metal-based structural components to composites has achieved great weight savings in many aerospace applications. One approach to further reduce the weight of the composite structures is to make the structures perform multiple tasks, i.e. make them multifunctional. The goal of such multifunctional structures (MFSs) is to incorporate various tasks within one structural housing. An example of MFS would be to combine structural, electrical, and thermal functions under one umbrella. The avionics in aircraft and aerospace structures comprises of various components such as electrical housing, supporting walls, cables, interconnects, spacers, and other parts. Avionics can account for anywhere between 20% and 40% of the weight of aerospace vehicles. The need for separate housing, walls, interconnects, etc., for avionics could be more or less eliminated by incorporating avionics into the structure itself, resulting in considerable weight savings.

There have been efforts in developing various types of MFSs. Rawal et al. [1] have demonstrated a working prototype of MFSs for the spacecraft avionics housing. The MFS was designed to replace the conventional avionics housing, wall support, thermal management units, interconnects, and wirings. This was a novel approach to reduce the weight by substantial amount. There were many challenges involving this integration of multiple functionalities. The use of novel thermal dissipating materials with the assistance of heat pipes were shown as one of the options. The multi-chip module with copper interconnect flex circuit board was used to embed avionics on top of a load-bearing composite structural unit. Das and Obal [2] have also mentioned similar effort being developed by AFRL.

There are a number of other ideas for integrating multiple functionality into the structural components. One of such ideas involves integrating structural and battery components for small-scale unnamed aerial vehicles (UAVs) [3, 4]. The lithium polymer battery is used to power the UAV flight as well as a structural component. This is an increasingly common practice in small- and mid-scaled UAV designs, where increasing payload capacity is a primary goal.

This article presents a sandwich beam as a MFS. Sandwich structures are widely used in aerospace industry for weight reduction and high bending stiffness applications. This study focuses on three critical parts of an MFS design: sandwich beam modifications, heat pipes, and thermal interface meterial (TIM). The first part of this study focuses on the idea of modifying a sandwich beam with cavity and various reinforcements for the cavity. The cavity can be used to embed avionics. The reinforcement methods are evaluated via three-point bending (TPB) and four-point bending (FPB) tests. The optimum densities of the reinforcements were determined, achieving almost 90% of the original sandwich beam strength.

The typical off-the-shelf electronics board has similar heat dissipation requirement as commercial mobile processors, 10 kW/m2 (1 W/cm2) during the normal operation. This heat needs to be dissipated to insure uninterrupted operations of avionics. The embedded electronics poses a great challenge for the design of heat dissipater and heat sink. The on-spot active cooling of such components are nearly impossible. So, passive cooling devices such as thermoelectric modules and heat pipes may be necessary. The second part of this study focuses on an innovative approach of heat dissipation using heat pipes and TIM.

There is a challenge in designing TIM for the embedded electronics. TIMs are responsible for efficient heat transfer from electronics surfaces to the heat sink. The TIMs considered in this study are mainly particulate composites with very high volume fractions of thermally conductive particles. The interfacial thermal resistance between the particle and the matrix plays an important role as the particle size becomes smaller and smaller. The third part of this study focuses on finding the optimum copper particle size for silicone/copper particulate composite TIM. The thermal interface resistance between copper and silicone elastomer was determined using a flash-laser technique. It is shown that this optimized TIM with heat pipes maintain embedded electronics within their thermal limits.

sec.title: MFS sandwich beam design and analysis
sec.p: The sample sandwich beam of a given dimension and foam core was taken as the baseline. This beam was then modified with a cavity created in the core to house avionics. The strength of the beam was expected to go down substantially due to the presence of this cavity. Various design methods were investigated for reinforcing the cavity to regain the lost strength. The reinforcement methods were tested for their efficiency with FPB and TPB tests.

sec.title: Design of the MFS sandwich beam
sec.p:
The sandwich beam with AS4/3501-6 carbon/epoxy sheets with lay-up sequence of [0/90]2S and general plastic polyurethane foam core of density 288.3 kg/m3 (18 lb/ft3) was selected as a sample structure. This selected configuration was based on typical carbon fiber reinforced plastic (CFRP) skin thickness and high-density core (e.g. aluminum) found in many aerospace applications. Figures 1 and 2 show sample specimens. The elastic moduli of AS4/3501-6 carbon/epoxy are given in Table 1 [5]. The General Plastic FR-6718 properties, as specified by vendor, are given in Table 2. Table 1.
Ply properties of AS4/3501-6 carbon/epoxy.
E1 140 GPa
E2 10 GPa
G12 6.9 GPa
v12 0.3
Table 2.
General plastic polyurethane foam FR-6718, 288.3 kg/m3(18 lb/ft3) properties.
Compressive strength 7296 kPa
Compressive modulus 213,208 kPa
Tensile strength 4838 kPa
Tensile modulus 237,100 kPa
Flexural strength 7665 kPa
Coefficient of thermal expansion −6.3 × 10−5 /degK
Thermal conductivity 0.054 W/m K
Figure 1.
The neat sandwich beam. Figure 2.
Sandwich beam with cavity for FPB test.
FPB: four-point bending.

sec.title: FPB test
sec.p:
The third method has an adverse effect in the case of point load applied right over the cavity. In that case, the sandwich beam would not be able to withstand a point load if the cavity is not filled. Reinforcing expandable foams of varying densities were used to fill the cavity and regain the lost strength of the sandwich beam. The FPB tests were performed on the 22-kip MTS machine. Figure 3 shows the loading geometry. The maximum failure loads were compared for each configuration. Figure 4 summarizes the FPB test results. Figure 3.
FPB loading geometry.
FPB: four-point bending. Figure 4.
Failure loads – FPB.
FPB: four-point bending.

From Figure 4, it is evident that the sandwich lost 66% of its strength once the cavity was created. The face sheet reinforcement in the cavity does a reasonably good job in reclaiming the lost strength. However, this configuration is not recommended if the load is applied directly above the cavity. The sandwich beam cavity filled with 80.1 kg/m3(5 lb/ft3) dense expandable foam performed much better than 32.0 kg/m3(2 lb/ft3) foam. It can be seen that sandwich beam recovered most of its bending strength, up to 87%, with 80.1 kg/m3(5 lb/ft3) expandable foam in the cavity.

sec.title: TPB test
sec.p:
The cavity was off-centered in the case of TPB. This prevents the structure from collapsing due to point load at the center. Figure 5 shows one of the test specimens with off-centered cavity. Figure 6 shows the loading geometry. The maximum failure loads were compared for each configuration. Figure 7 summarizes the results for TPB tests. Figure 5.
TPB test specimens with cavity.
TPB: three-point bending. Figure 6.
TPB loading geometry.
TPB: three-point bending. Figure 7.
Failure loads – TPB.
TPB: three-point bending. Figure 8.
Animation – working of a heat pipe [5].

The sandwich beam with cavity performed very poorly under the TPB test. The cavity was then filled with 80.1 kg/m3(5 lb/ft3) expandable foam. The structure regained very small amount of strength in this configuration. The failure load was 20% of the original sandwich. The failure started at the corners of the cavity. The corners were stiffen with Al angles in the next configuration. This would partially eliminate high stress concentration at the cavity corners. The results did improve under this case, but only marginally. The cavity with 80.1 kg/m3(5 lb/ft3) expandable foam and Al angle still had only 33% of the original sandwich strength. It was necessary to fill the cavity with higher than 80.1 kg/m3(5 lb/ft3) to recover most of the lost strength. As seen from Figure 7, the strength of the sandwich was recovered (up to 87%) when cavity was filled with 240.3 kg/m3(15 lb/ft3) expandable foam.

sec.title: Heat dissipation using heat pipe
sec.p: The heat dissipation of embedded electronics is a challenging task. Heat should be channeled from the cavity to the proper dissipater to insure the reliable functionality of the structural and electrical components. Due to the current design of the MFS, it is not possible to use traditional methods of heat dissipation like fans, liquid cooling, etc.

sec.title: Heat pipes
sec.p: Heat pipes are passive heat transfer devices. It works on the principle of heat transfer via capillary actions of fluid particles. Heat pipes consist of three main parts: a hollow tube, working fluid, and a capillary wicking material. The capillary wicking material is attached to the inside wall of a metal tube. The working fluid is a pressurized liquid (water, coolan, etc). Due to the capillary action, heat pipes can work against the gravity. Heat is taken in by one end and is channeled through the capillary wicking material via evaporation of the working fluid to the cold end. At the cold end, vapor condenses to liquid, which returns to the heating end and the cycle continues. Heat is exchanged via latent heat of evaporation and condensation of the working fluid. The movement of fluid is so fast that the effective thermal conductivity of the heat pipe is a couple of orders of magnitude greater than copper.

One way to judge the performance of heat pipes is to measure the temperature drop between the two ends a heat pipe during its operation. If heat pipe can take all the heat from the electronics to the heat dissipator very rapidly, then it should have a uniform temperature along its length. In practice, it is desirable to achieve very small temperature difference between the two ends of the heat pipe. Heat pipe reaches its threshold when the temperature difference between the two ends becomes very high. That particular thermal load is said to be the working limit of a given heat pipe. Table 3 lists the result of the two commercially available heat pipes. The data are provided by Dell/HP as an example of a typical heat pipe performance required by mobile computing industry. It is evident that the heat pipe performance is acceptable up to 30 W. Table 3.
Heat pipe performance
Power (W) Average temperature drop (°C) – YCTC Average temperature drop (°C) – Hitachi
20 3.75 5.4
25 4.75 6.6
27 5.25 7.2
35 11.25 9.4
40 20.90 10.73

sec.title: Heat dissipation
sec.p:
In this study, a single-source heating element with one flat heat pipe was used to demonstrate the real-world application, as shown in Figure 9. Fan cooling was used at the condenser end to represent slow subsonic air velocity. The temperature difference between the condenser (heat-in) and evaporator (heat-out) ends was measured to map the feasibility and efficiency of the heat pipe. The sample heat pipe used for the experiments, Figure 9, was the sample unit used in some of the shipping laptops from large OEMs like HP and Dell (as of 2006). Figure 9.
Single heating element.

Figure 10 represents the results for the single heat source. It is seen that the temperature drop across the heat pipe increases as the input power is increased. Considering typical commercial electronics are required to be operated below 60°C, the experimental result indicates that the heat pipe did an acceptable job up to 15 W. After that, the temperature drop (dT) was more than 30°C, indicating difficultly in removing heat. This method of heat dissipation can also be extended for multiple adjacent heat sources. Figure 10.
dT across the heat pipe vs power input.

sec.title: Particulate composite TIM design
sec.p: The materials used that are between electronics and heat dissipater are called TIMs, which are usually dielectric rubber or gel-type materials used between electronics and heat sink. These materials are electrically insulative with reasonably good thermal conductivity. There are various types of TIMs available in the market in the form of elastomers or gels. The elastomers are useful in applications where leakage and thickness of the material is a main concern. The gel-type material cannot be used effectively as a thick TIM (4 mm and above). For the present application, elastomers are more suitable to transfer the heat to the surface of the sandwich structure for heat dissipation.

Pure silicone or epoxy-based materials do not have a good thermal conductivity; they are usually mixed with high thermal conductive particles like copper, alumina, diamond, etc., to achieve better effective conductivity. There are various theoretical models [6–10] to predict the thermal conductivity of such particulate composites. The rule of mixtures has been used in the past to predict the composite conductivity, but it does not yield accurate results. The micromechanics-type approaches [8] predict much better thermal conductivity of composite media, but even then there have been some discrepancies in the prediction and experimental result.

The knowledge of thermal resistance between the particle and host medium is required to use all these micromechanics models. In the ideal situation, the interfacial contact between the particle and the host medium would cause little temperature discontinuity. However, due to imperfect particle–matrix interfaces, a temperature discontinuity exists at the particle–matrix interface for steady-state heat transfer. There are various studies on interfacial thermal resistance in particulate composite TIMs [11–14]. This is an important parameter as the size of the particles used in TIMs becomes smaller. It has been shown that, for the same particle volume fraction, decreasing particle size can adversely affect the composite thermal conductivity [15]. This is due to the fact that as the size of the conductive particle becomes smaller, the interfacial area increases and the interfacial thermal resistance becomes more dominant.

sec.title: Copper–Silicone interfacial thermal resistance
sec.p:
Copper has very high thermal conductivity among metals, and silicone is used widely to make TIMs because of its balanced dielectric and thermal properties. In this study, the silicon elastomer from Dow-Corning was used to make a two-layered copper–silicone composite, as shown in Figure 11, for the investigation of interfacial thermal resistance. Figure 11.
Sample used for thermal boundary resistance measurement.

The flash-laser technique was used to measure the interfacial thermal resistance of the two-layered TIM. The interface resistance can then be used to accurately model multiple-layered TIMs or other copper-particle/silicone composite TIMs. The laser-flash involves transient thermal measurement technique. The laser is shot on the front surface of the specimen while temperature rise is measured at the back center of the specimen. The experiment was carried out by Thermophysical Measurement Laboratory (TPRL) located in the Purdue Research Park.

The reading of temperature rise with respect to time is taken via an infrared probe. The voltage reading was converted into the corresponding temperature scale by a constant calibration factor of machine, resulting in the temperature rise history, as shown in Figure 12. Figure 12.
Temperature rise vs time.

The thermal diffusivity is calculated from Parker's equation as (1)α=0.1388l2t1/2 where t1/2 is half of the time for the temperature to reach the maximum value and the length parameter ‘l’ the total thickness of the sample. The conductivity of the material can be calculated using the diffusivity, specific heat, and density of the material (2)K=Cpρα

For experiment, the material constants of copper were taken from the literature and values for silicone elastomer were measured by TPRL. The specific heat was measured by ASTM standard differential scanning calorimetry method. The interfacial thermal resistance was calculated using the material constants given in Table 4. Multiple readings were taken and results are presented in Table 5. Table 4.
Parameters for two-layer composite sample
Layer Si elastomer Copper
Thickness (cm) 0.1584 0.0467
Cp (K/g/K) 1.46 0.389
Density (gm/cm3) 1.042 8.96
Diffusivity (cm2/s) 0.00094 1.17
Conductivity (W/cm-K) 0.00143 4.08
Thermal resistance 110.7 0.0115
Table 5.
Thermal boundary resistance results
Temperature (°C) Rc (cm2 K/W)
23 0.0179
23 0.0131
23 0.0117
23 0.0147
23 0.0131
23 0.0183
Average 0.0148

From the above data, it is evident that the interfacial thermal resistance of the Si–Cu interface is rather low. It is an order of magnitude of copper and 10,000 times lower than the silicone elastomer. Such a low thermal boundary resistance indicate a very good bond between the copper platelet and silicone elastomer.

sec.title: Design guidelines for TIM
sec.p: From the result of the interfacial thermal resistance study, it is obvious that the best layered Si–Cu TIM is a sandwich construction with thin silicone faces and a copper core. However, such a construction will make the TIM too stiff for applications where compliant properties are desired. One possible solution would be to use composite made up of small copper platelets and silicone matrix. However, the use of thin copper platelets or copper particles of different shapes may reduce the effective thermal conductivity of the composite TIM because of the increasing number of particle–matrix interfaces. Thus, the size of copper particles must be carefully optimized between the compliance and thermal conductivity requirements.

From Davis and Artz [15] the thermal conductivity K of a particulate composite can be given as (3)KKm=[Kp(1+2h)+2Km]+2vf[Kp(1-h)-Km][Kp(1+2h)+2Km]-vf[Kp(1-h)-Km] where subscripts m and p represent matrix and particle, respectively, vf the volume fraction of particles, and (4)h=RcKma
From the above two equations, we can calculate the critical particle size at which composite K is same as Km (5)a0=RcKm1-Km/KmKpKp

Consider a particulate TIM consisting of copper (401 W/m K) and silicone matrix (0.143 W/m K). The boundary resistance is given in Table 5. This gives us the critical particle size for copper–silicone based composite as a0= 0.2 micron or 2 × 10−7 m. This means that adding particles of diameter less than 0.4 micron will make the thermal conductivity of TIM lower than that of the matrix. This particle size represents the threshold for Si–Cu composite TIM. Figure 13 shows the variation of relative composite thermal conductivity with respect to particle size for two volume fractions of copper in silicone elastomer. A sharp decrease in the TIM conductivity can be avoided using these guidelines and Figure 13. Figure 13.
Relationship of particle size vs relative conductivity of Si–Cu TIM.
TIM: thermal interface material.

sec.title: Integrated cooling system for UAVs
sec.p:
Now, we have all the necessary experimental data to calculate the cooling of the embedded electronics. The thermal dissipation efficiency of the embedded system can be evaluated using these data. The cavity cut-away is represented in Figure 14. Both aluminum and CFRP face sheets were considered for this model, representing most of the current mid-sized and full-scaled UAV skins. Figure 14.
Cut away of sandwich cavity with embedded electronics.

The steady-state heat transfer analysis was performed to evaluate the steady working temperature of the embedded avionics. The equivalent steady-state thermal circuit of the cavity is represented in Figure 15. The calculations for the various parameters of steady-state thermal resistance circuit represented in Figure 15 are described below:
Electronics aka heat source: The thermal load of the electronics is considered as equivalent of 10 kW/m2. Most of the modern electronics have temperature limits of about 75–80°C. The power dissipation of 10 kW is on the higher side of typical avionics, thus conservative estimate. The sandwich structure considered for this study can accommodate electronics heat generating surface of about 32.26 cm2 (5 in2). Considering thermal load of 10 kW/m2, the total power output, Q, for 32.26 cm2 area should be 30 W.
TIM: TIM is placed over the electronics for electrical insulation and to improve heat transfer between electronics and heat dissipation network. The Cu–Si micron-sized TIM can have thermal conductivity of 0.75 W/m K using the copper particle sizes discussed in the above sections. The thickness of the TIM material on the top of the electronics are usually determined by the dielectric property of the material. The polymer-based TIM should use thickness between 0.5 and 1 mm to achieve a proper dielectric strength. The thickness of 1 mm is considered for the current model. The total resistance RTIM can be computed as (6)RTIM=LTIMKTIMATIM Substituting the considered thickness, conductivity and surface area of the TIM (same as surface area of heat source), we get RTIM = 0.413 K/W.
Heat pipes network: Heat pipes can be integrated in the cavity to transfer heat rapidly from electronics to outer surface. The experimental results above suggest that the heat pipes have thermal conductivity of 2000 W/m K, ∼ 5x of copper. The typical embedded electronics are considered to be integrated inside a cavity length of 5.08 cm (2 in). This means heat pipes need to be around 5 cm long to reach the metal/composite surface. The heat pipes are considered to have a cross section of 1 cm in diameter. The thermal resistance of heat pipes alone can be calculated as (7)Rhp=LhpKhpAhp This gives the thermal resistance of the heat pipe Rhp = 0.32 K/W. The heat pipes are placed over TIM on one side (neat electronics), but they also need to be connected on the other side, on metal or composite skin, using TIM. The TIM on the other end of the heat pipe does not have to be particulate composite as there is no electrical insulation requirement. For this purpose, low dielectric strength but better thermal conductive TIM can used to connect the heat pipe to the metal or composite skin of the vehicle. One of such readily available grease/glue-type TIM is OmegaBond, by Omega Inc. The thermal conductivity of OmegaBond is 2.3 W/m K. Thus, the thermal resistance of a thin layer (0.2 mm) of OmegaBond can be accounted as an additional resistance in the circuit. This gives ROmegaBond = 0.277 K/W. The total resistance of the heat pipe network include resistance of individual heat pipes plus resistance due to the OmegaBond layer. Figure 15.
Equivalent resistive circuit for steady-state heat transfer. The total resistance of one heat pipe network: Rhp + ROmegaBond = 0.595 K/W. The total resistance of two heat pipes (in parallel) network: (Rhp + ROmegaBond)/2 = 0.298 K/W.
Metallic and/or composite skin: The typical UAV or aircraft skins are made up of aluminum or composite. This model gives steady-state temperature of both aluminum and composite skins. The typical thickness of these skins are around 1 mm. The laminar flow is considered over an external surface of a large UAV or an aircraft. The turbulent boundary layers have higher heat transfer coefficients, so laminar flow is a conservative approach. The skin with laminar flow can have a surface area of up to 0.5 m2. For the current conservative approach, it is considered that only 1/10 of that external surface area, 0.05 m2 (0.5 × 0.1 m), is available for heat dissipation. The thermal resistance of skin, Rskin, can be calculated as (8)Rskin=LskinKskinAskin Considering typical thermal conductivity of aluminum as 180 W/m K and typical transverse conductivity of carbon fiber composite as 1.4 W/m K, we get Rskin−Al = 0.00011 and Rskin−composite = 0.0143
Convective cooling: The natural air cooling is used for the steady-state model of the MFS. The full-scaled UAV or aircraft can be cruised at a speed 0.4–0.5 Mach depending on its size. The convective cooling temperatures for up to 100 m/s (∼Mach 0.3) are predicted in the current model, higher velocities would enable faster cooling. The laminar flow assumption is enforced by considering a Reynolds number 3 × 105 or less [16,17]. The Nusselt and Prandtl numbers need to be calculated to determine the heat transfer coefficient of a laminar flow over a flat plate. The Prandtl number, Pr, is a non-dimensional ratio of viscous boundary layer thickness to the thermal boundary layer thickness. It can be calculated using standard air properties from equations [16,17] (9)⪻=να=Cpμk The Nusselt number for plate of length L can be found from Prandtl number as (10)NuL=0.664(⪻)1/3ReL (11)ReL=ρu∞Lμ This gives the convective heat transfer coefficient as (12)hplate=kLNuL This heat transfer coefficient can be used to find the thermal resistance for convection. (13)Rplate=hplateAplate Using the standard air properties from references [16] and [17] and geometrical properties considered for the current structure, one can calculate Rplate for various velocities.

The temperature of the embedded chip for various air velocities and varying numbers of heat pipes can be evaluated from the above model. Figure 16 represents the steady-state temperature difference between the surrounding and the embedded avionics. A temperature difference of 45°C or less would insure proper functioning of the embedded electronics. Aluminum is a better conductor than the composite, so aluminum skin is more efficient. But, composite performs well and keeps electronics within their thermal limits. As seen from the graph, using multiple heat pipes helps to rapidly reject heat. Figure 16.
Temperature difference with surrounding vs air velocity.

In the above model, maximum thermal resistance was due to TIM. The convective cooling, heat pipes, and aluminum face sheets are at least an order of magnitude better heat conductor than the TIM. Thus, advancements in TIM performance and design are desirable for embedding more power hungry avionics in the cavity.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The design and analysis of UAV MFSs is provided with the emphasis on three critical areas – sandwich structure, heat pipes, and TIM. The innovative design of the sandwich beam and its cavity reinforcement methods retains structural strength even after embedding avionics. The efficient thermal management system, using particulate TIM and heat pipes, insures proper functioning of the embedded avionics. It is shown that the design is a feasible approach for the UAVs operating at subsonic speeds. The weight savings by adopting MFS design would enable UAVs to carry higher payloads and reduce fuel burn.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by a grant from the Indiana 21st Century Research and Technology Fund.
